title: The Concept of Stripping Down the Black Terminals?
content:
Previously, I started a thread about [The Concept of Stripping Down the Serifs](http://web.archive.org/web/20140804024923/http:/www.typophile.com/node/114952).  
Now, let's go back to time, back to the Middle Age.  
I still wonder who first conceives sans serif typefaces based on blackletter calligraphy? Should I say **Blackletter Sans** , in other words, blackletter without terminals.  
William Morris, Rudolf Koch or Tom Carnase and his [_Honda_](http://web.archive.org/web/20140804024923/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/honda/)?  
Some recent designers work and exploit geometric moduls combined with a heavy weight which give the flavor of blackletter: see [_Trigot_](http://web.archive.org/web/20140804024923/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/volcano/trigot/) or [_Griffensee_](http://web.archive.org/web/20140804024923/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/catharsis-fonts/gryffensee/).  
Fell free to give your interpretation. Thanks for your input.
author: Fournier

comments.content: The vulgar name for them in Germany was/is "Schaftstiefelgrotesk", as I recall. This link should be good as a starting point: [http://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gebrochene\_Grotesk](http://web.archive.org/web/20140804024923/http:/de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gebrochene_Grotesk) (Worst case, you can try throwing this link at a machine translator.)

William Morris' [_Troy_](http://web.archive.org/web/20140804024923/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/p22/morris/troy/) fits the actual concept of **Neo-Blackletter** or **Blackletter Sans**.

Tom Carnase's [_ITC Honda_](http://web.archive.org/web/20140804024923/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/honda/) (1970) has not only the **Blackletter Sans** leaning but combined with the weight of a slab serif/fat face if you catch my meaning.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140804024923im_/http:/typophile.com/files/honda_6736.gif)

I found another lead concerning the concept through Eric Gill's [_Jubilee_](http://web.archive.org/web/20140804024923/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/redrooster/jubilee-rr/).  
What do you think of Gill's [_Jubilee_](http://web.archive.org/web/20140804024923/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/redrooster/jubilee-rr/) and its cognitive bias?
Were there a humanist-sans blackletter style, Jubilee would probably be it.
